The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: THE MYSTERIE OF THE LORDS SVPPER.
CLEERELY MANIFESTED IN FIVE SERMONS; Two of Preparation, and Three of the Sacrament it Å¿elfe.
BY A REVEREND AND FAITHfull Preacher of Gods word.

q.p: WhoÅ¿oeuer eateth my fleÅ¿h, and drinketh my blood, hath eternall life, and I will raiÅ¿e him vp at the laÅ¿t day.
It is the Spirit that quickeneth; the fleÅ¿h profiteth nothing: the words that I Å¿peake vnto you are Å¿pirit and life.

div.head: THE PRINTER TO THE READER.
div.p:
I PreÅ¿ent here vnto thy viewe (good reader) a learned and godly treatiÅ¿e, wherein the Doctrine of the Lords Å¿upper is both plainely and fully handled. A worke which heretofore hath beene in diuers mens hands, yet not without Å¿ome inconuenience; for being at firÅ¿t borne in another Å¿oyle then our owne, it was written in a language (though but the Å¿ame, with ours in Å¿ubÅ¿tance) yet by reaÅ¿on of the peculiar dialect or propriety Å¿o often varying, and more then Å¿ufficient to make them that are not throughly acquainted with the difference, to miÅ¿take euen things that to our vnderÅ¿tanding are much more familiar then the holy myÅ¿teries of our Å¿aluation. The conÅ¿ideratioÌ of which incommodity did moue a worthy and truly religious Gentleman M. S. Michell, to take the paines to peruÅ¿e and poliÅ¿he Å¿o good a worke to the
end to publiÅ¿h it, that Å¿o it might be profitable to all: But hauing Å¿carÅ¿e finiÅ¿hed and prepared it for the preÅ¿Å¿e, it pleaÅ¿ed God to take him to himÅ¿elfe, before he could Å¿ee a finall end of this, and many other his religious and honeÅ¿t endeauors, yet leaÅ¿t the Church Å¿hould haue loÅ¿t Å¿o precious a Iewell (his zeale of good doing continuing vnto the end) he committed the execution of this Å¿o godly a deÅ¿ire, to the Å¿peciall care of one of his good and truÅ¿ty friends, who being faithfull in the truÅ¿t committed vnto him is a principal meanes that now it commeth Å¿afely to thy hands; receiue it therefore and eÅ¿teeme it (as the moÅ¿t godly and iudicious haue euer done) the beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t profitable treatiÅ¿e that euer hath bin publiÅ¿hed of this Å¿ubiect, and ceaÅ¿e not to thanke God for raiÅ¿ing vp Å¿o many meanes to procure thy good, whoÅ¿e Å¿ole end in all their labours is Gods glory, and the furthering of thy true happineÅ¿Å¿e. Farewell.

closer.signed: Thine in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, F. B.

div.head: The firÅ¿t Sermon vpon the Sacraments in generall.

epigraph.q: For I haue receiued of the Lord, that which I alÅ¿o haue deliuered vnto you, to wit, that the Lord IeÅ¿us in the night that he was betrayed, tooke Bread, &c.

div.p:
THere is nothing in this world, nor out of this world, more to be wiÅ¿hed of euery one of you, more to be craued, and Å¿ought, of euery one of you, then to bee conioyned with ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, then once to be made one, with the God of glory, ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. This heauenly, and celeÅ¿tiall coniunction, is purchaÅ¿ed and brought about, by two Å¿peciall meanes; It is brought about, by meanes of the word and preaching of the GoÅ¿pell: and it is brought about, by the meanes of the Sacraments, and miniÅ¿tration thereof.
The word leadeth vs to ChriÅ¿t, by the eare; the Sacraments, lead vs to ChriÅ¿t, by the eye: Two Å¿enÅ¿es, of all the reÅ¿t, which God hath choÅ¿en, as moÅ¿t meet for this purpoÅ¿e, to inÅ¿truct vs, and bring vs vnto ChriÅ¿t. For that doctrine muÅ¿t be moÅ¿t effectuall, & mouing, that wakeneth and Å¿tirreth vp moÅ¿t of the outward Å¿enÅ¿es: that doctrine, that wakeneth not onely the eare, but the eye, the taÅ¿te, the feeling, and all the reÅ¿t of the outward Å¿enÅ¿es, muÅ¿t moue the heart moÅ¿t, muÅ¿t be moÅ¿t effectuall, and pearcing in the Å¿oule. But Å¿o it is, that this doctrine of the Sacraments, moues, Å¿tirres vp, and wakens moÅ¿t of the outward Å¿enÅ¿es, therfore it muÅ¿t bee (if wee come well prepared vnto it) moÅ¿t effectuall to Å¿tirre vp the inward Å¿enÅ¿es of the dull heart. But there is a thing, that yee muÅ¿t euer remember; there is no doctrine, neither of the Å¿imple word, nor yet of the Sacraments, if ChriÅ¿t abÅ¿tract his holy Å¿pirit, that is able to moue: therefore, when euer yee come to heare the doctrine, whether it be of the Sacraments, or of the Å¿imple word, craue of God, that
hee would be preÅ¿ent by his holy Å¿pirit, or otherwiÅ¿e all the doctrine in the earth will not awaile you. Alwaies, this doctrine of the Sacraments, Å¿tirres vp, and wakens moÅ¿t of the outward Å¿enÅ¿es, and therefore there is no queÅ¿tion, but it is an effectuall, and potent inÅ¿trument, to waken, prepare, and Å¿tirre vp our hearts.

Then to let you Å¿ee what the word Sacrament meaneth: The diuerÅ¿e taking of the word Sacrament. and to remoue the ambiguitie of it, it is certaine, and out of all queÅ¿tion, that the Latine Diuines, who were moÅ¿t ancient, did interpret the Greeke word ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , by the word Sacrament; and they vÅ¿ed the Greeke word, not onely to Å¿ignifie the whole action of the Supper of the Lord, and the whole action of BaptiÅ¿me: but they vÅ¿ed the word MyÅ¿tery, to Å¿ignifie whatÅ¿oeuer is darke, and bid in it Å¿elfe, and not frequented in the common vÅ¿e of men: as after this manner, the ApoÅ¿tle calleth the vocation of the Gentiles a myÅ¿terie.
EpheÅ¿ 3.9. EpheÅ¿. 5.32. This coniunction which is begun heere betwixt vs and ChriÅ¿t, is called a MyÅ¿terie; and the Latine Interpreters, call it a
Sacrament: and to be Å¿hort, ye will not finde in the booke of God a word more frequent, then the word MyÅ¿terie. But as for the word Sacrament, wherby they interpret the Greeke word, we finde not this word by the Å¿ame Diuines to be taken Å¿o largely; neither is it takeÌ Å¿o largely in any part of the booke of God. Alwayes the word Sacrament, is very ambiguous in it Å¿elfe, and there ariÅ¿eth about the ambiguitie of this word many controuerÅ¿ies, which are not yet ceaÅ¿ed, nor will not ceaÅ¿e while the world laÅ¿teth: whereas if they had kept the ApoÅ¿tles words, and called them as the ApoÅ¿tle calleth them, Signes, and Seales; all this digladiation, Å¿trife and contention, appearingly had not fallen out: but where men will be wiÅ¿er then God, and giue names to things without warrant from God, vpon the wit of man, which is but meere folly, all this Å¿tirre falleth out. Well then, to come vnto the purpoÅ¿e; The ancient Diuines tooke the word Sacrament, as we may perceiue, in a fourefold manner: Sometime they tooke it for the whole action; that is, the whole
miniÅ¿tery of the Elements: Å¿ometime, they tooke it not for the whole action, but for the outward things, that are vÅ¿ed in the action of BaptiÅ¿me, and of the Supper, as they tooke it, for the vvater, and Å¿prinkling of it; for the Bread and Wine breaking, diÅ¿tributing, and eating thereof. Thirdly againe, they tooke it not for the whole outward things, that are vÅ¿ed in the action, but onely for the materiall, and earthly things, the Elements: as, for Bread and Wine in the Supper, and water in BaptiÅ¿me. And after this Å¿ort, Å¿aith AuguÅ¿tine, the wicked eate the body of our Lord, concerning the Sacrament onely, that is, concerning the Elements onely. LaÅ¿t of all they tooke it not only for the Elements, but for the things Å¿ignified by the Elements. And after this manner, Irenaeus Å¿aith, that a Sacrament Å¿tandeth of two things: the one, earthly; the other, heauenly. The ancient Diuines then, taking the word after theÅ¿e Å¿orts, no queÅ¿tion, all theÅ¿e waies they tooke it rightly.

But leauing the ambiguitie of the word, I take the word Sacrament, as it is
taken, and vÅ¿ed this day in the Church of GOD, for a holy Signe and Seale that is annexed to the preached word of God, to Å¿eale vp and confirme the truth contained in the Å¿ame vvord: Å¿o that I call not the Å¿eale, Å¿eparated from the vvord a Sacrament. For, as there can not bee a Å¿eale, but that which is the Å¿eale of an euidence, and if the Å¿eale be Å¿eparated from the euidence, it is not a Å¿eale, but looke what it is by nature, it is no more: So there cannot bee a Sacrament, except it bee annexed to the euidence of the vvord; but looke what the Sacrament was by nature, it is no more. Was it a common peece of bread? it remaines common bread, except it be ioyned to the euidence of the vvord. Therefore the vvord onelie cannot be a Sacrament, nor the element onely, cannot be a Sacrament; but the vvord and element coniunctly, muÅ¿t make a Sacrament. And Å¿o Augustine Å¿aid well, Let the vvord come to the element, and Å¿o yee Å¿hall haue a Sacrament. So then, the vvord muÅ¿t come to the element: that is, the vvord preached
diÅ¿tinctly, and all the parts of it opened vp, muÅ¿t goe before the hanging to of the Å¿acrament; and the Sacrament as a Å¿eale muÅ¿t follow, and Å¿o be receiued accordingly.

Then I call a Sacrament, the vvord and Å¿eale coniunctly, the one hung to the other. It is without all controuerÅ¿ie, and there is no doubt in it, that all Sacraments are Å¿ignes: Now if a Sacrament be a Å¿igne, as the Å¿igne is in a relation, in that Category, for Å¿o wee muÅ¿t Å¿peake it: Å¿o the Sacrament muÅ¿t be placed in that Å¿ame Category of relation. Now euery relation againe muÅ¿t Å¿tand of force betwixt two things; for one thing cannot bee the correlatiue of it Å¿elfe: but in a lawfull relation, of force there muÅ¿t be two things, which two, haue euer a mutuall reÅ¿pect the one to the other: therfore, in euery Sacrament that hath a relation, there muÅ¿t be two things, which two haue euer a mutual reÅ¿pect the one to the other.

Take away one of theÅ¿e two things from the Sacrament, ye loÅ¿e the relation; & loÅ¿ing the relation, ye loÅ¿e the Sacrament.
Confound any of theÅ¿e two with the other, make either a confuÅ¿ion or permixtion of them, ye loÅ¿e the relation: and loÅ¿ing the relation, ye loÅ¿e the Sacrament. Turne ouer the one into the other, Å¿o that the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the one, Å¿tarts vp, and vaniÅ¿heth in the other; yee loÅ¿e the relation, and Å¿o yee loÅ¿e the Sacrament. Then as in euery Sacrament there is a relation; Å¿o to keepe the relation, yee muÅ¿t euer keepe two things Å¿euerally in the Sacrament.

Now, The heads to be entreated in this SermoÌ. for the better vnderÅ¿tanding & coÌÅ¿ideration of theÅ¿e two diuerÅ¿e things, which are relatiue to others, wee Å¿hall keepe this order by Gods grace. FirÅ¿t, I will let you Å¿ee what is meant by a Å¿igne in the Sacrament. Next, I wil let you vnderÅ¿tand, what is meant by the thing Å¿ignified. Thirdly, how they two are coupled; by what power and vertue they are conioyned; & from whence this power and vertue floweth. Fourthly, and laÅ¿t of all, I will let you vnderÅ¿tand, whether one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame inÅ¿trument, giues the Å¿igne, and the thing Å¿ignified, or not; whether they be giuen in one action, or
two; whether they be offred to one inÅ¿trument, or two; or if they be giuen after one manner, or two, to both the inÅ¿truments. Marke theÅ¿e diuerÅ¿ities; the diuerÅ¿e manner of the receiuing, the diuerÅ¿itie of the InÅ¿truments, and the diuerÅ¿itie of the giuers: and yee Å¿hall finde little difficultie in the Sacrament.

Now, to beginne at the Å¿ignes, Å¿eeing all Sacraments are Å¿ignes, The Å¿ignes in the Sacrament. what call wee the Å¿ignes in the Sacrament? I call the Å¿ignes in the Sacrament, whatÅ¿oeuer I perceiue, and take vp by my outward Å¿enÅ¿es, by mine eye eÅ¿pecially. Now ye Å¿ee in this Sacrament, there are two Å¿orts of things Å¿ubiect to the outward Å¿enÅ¿es, & to the eye eÅ¿pecially: yee Å¿ee the Elements of Bread and Wine are Å¿ubiect to mine eye; therfore they muÅ¿t be Å¿ignes. Yee Å¿ee againe, that the rites and ceremonies, whereby theÅ¿e Elements are diÅ¿tributed, broken, and giuen, are Å¿ubiect to mine eye alÅ¿o: Then I muÅ¿t make two Å¿orts of Å¿ignes; one Å¿ort of the Bread and the Wine, and we call them Elementall: another Å¿ort of the rites & ceremonies, whereby theÅ¿e are diÅ¿tributed, broken,
and giuen, and wee call them ceremoniall. Be not deceiued with the vvord Ceremonie; thinke not, that I call the breaking of the Bread, the eating of the Bread, and drinking of the Wine, Ceremonies: thinke not that they are vaine, as yee vÅ¿e that word Ceremonie for a vaine thing, which hath no grace, nor profit, following after it. No, although I call them Ceremonies, there is neuer a Ceremonie which ChriÅ¿t inÅ¿tituted in this Supper, but it is as eÅ¿Å¿entiall, as the Bread and Wine are, and yee cannot leaue one iot of them, except yee peruert the whole inÅ¿titution: for what euer ChriÅ¿t commaunded to be done, what euer he Å¿pake, or did, in that whole action, it is eÅ¿Å¿entiall, and muÅ¿t be done; and yee cannot leaue one iot thereof, but yee vvill peruert the vvhole action.

The reaÅ¿on, wherefore I call them Å¿ignes, Why they are called Å¿ignes. is this: I call them not Å¿ignes by that reaÅ¿on that men commonly call them Å¿ignes, becauÅ¿e they Å¿ignifie onely; as the Bread Å¿ignifies the body of ChriÅ¿t, & the Wine Å¿ignifies the bloud of ChriÅ¿t:
I call them not Å¿ignes becauÅ¿e they repreÅ¿ent onely; but I call them Å¿ignes, becauÅ¿e they haue the body and bloud of ChriÅ¿t conioyned with them. Yea, Å¿o truly is the body of ChriÅ¿t conioyned with that Bread, and the bloud of ChriÅ¿t conioyned with that Wine, that as Å¿oone as thou receiueÅ¿t that Bread in thy mouth (if thou be a faithful man or woman) Å¿o Å¿oone receiueÅ¿t thou the bodie of ChriÅ¿t in thy Å¿oule, and that by faith: and as Å¿oone as thou receiueÅ¿t that Wine in thy mouth, Å¿o Å¿oone thou receiueÅ¿t the bloud of ChriÅ¿t in thy Å¿oule, and that by faith: In reÅ¿pect of this exhibition chiefely, that they are inÅ¿truments to deliuer, and exhibite the things that they Å¿ignifie, and not in reÅ¿pect onely of their repreÅ¿entation, are they called Å¿ignes. For if they did nothing but repreÅ¿ent, or Å¿ignifie a thing abÅ¿ent; then any picture, or dead Image Å¿hould be a Sacrament: for there is no picture, as the picture of the King, but at the Å¿ight of the picture, the King vvill come in your minde, and it vvill Å¿ignifie vnto you, that, that is the Kings picture: So, if the
Å¿igne of the Sacrament did no further, all pictures Å¿hould bee Sacraments: but in reÅ¿pect the Sacrament exhibites, and deliuers the thing that it Å¿ignifieth, to the Å¿oule and hart, Å¿o Å¿oone as the Å¿igne is deliuered to the mouth, for this cauÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially, it is called a Å¿igne. There is no picture of the King, that will deliuer the King vnto you; there is no other Image, that will exhibite the thing, wherof it is the Image: therefore there is no Image can be a Sacrament. Then, in reÅ¿pect the Lord hath appointed the Sacraments, as hands to deliuer, and exhibite the thing Å¿ignified, for this deliuery, and exhibition chiefely, they are called Å¿ignes. As the word of the GoÅ¿pel, is a mighty & potent inÅ¿trument to our euerlaÅ¿ting Å¿aluation: Å¿o the Sacrament is a potent inÅ¿trument, appointed by GOD, to deliuer vs to ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, to our euerlaÅ¿ting Å¿aluation. For this Å¿pirituall meat, is dreÅ¿Å¿ed, and giuen vp to vs in Å¿pirituall diÅ¿hes: that is, in the miniÅ¿tery of the word, and in the miniÅ¿tery of the Sacraments. And Å¿uppoÅ¿e this miniÅ¿tery be externall, yet the Lord is
Å¿aid to deliuer Å¿pirituall, and heauenlie things, by theÅ¿e externall things. Why? BecauÅ¿e hee hath appointed them as inÅ¿truments, whereby he will deliuer his owne Sonne vnto vs. For this is certain, that none hath power to deliuer ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us vnto vs, except God, and his holy Å¿pirit: and therefore, to Å¿peake properly, there is none can deliuer ChriÅ¿t, but God by his owne Å¿pirit: hee is deliuered by the miniÅ¿tery of the holy Spirit; it is the holy Spirit, that Å¿eales him vp in our harts, and confirmes vs more and more in him: as the ApoÅ¿tle giues him this Å¿tile, 2. Cor. 1.22.

To Å¿peak properly, there is none hath power to deliuer ChriÅ¿t, but GOD the Father, or himÅ¿elfe. There is none hath power to deliuer the Mediator, but his owne Å¿pirit: yet it hath pleaÅ¿ed GOD, to vÅ¿e Å¿ome inÅ¿truments and means, wherby hee will deliuer ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us vnto vs. The meanes are theÅ¿e; the miniÅ¿tery of the vvord, and the miniÅ¿tery of the Sacraments; and in reÅ¿pect he vÅ¿eth theÅ¿e as meanes, to deliuer ChriÅ¿t, they are Å¿aid to deliuer him. But heere yee haue
to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h, between the principall efficient deliuerer, and the inÅ¿trumentall efficient; which is, the word, and the SacrameÌts: keeping this diÅ¿tinction, both theÅ¿e are true; GOD by his word, and GOD by his Å¿pirit, deliuereth ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us vnto you. Then I Å¿ay, I cal theÌ Å¿ignes, becauÅ¿e God hath made them potent inÅ¿truments, to deliuer that Å¿ame thing which they Å¿ignifie.

Now I goe to the thing Å¿ignified, and I call the thing Å¿ignified by the Å¿ignes in the Sacrament, What is the thing Å¿ignified in the Sacrament. that, which Irenaeus, that old Writer, calleth, the heauenly & Å¿pirituall thing: to wit, whole ChriÅ¿t, with his whole gifts, benefites, and graces, applyed, & giuen to my Å¿oule. Then I call not the thing Å¿ignified, by the Å¿ignes of Bread and Wine; the benefits of ChriÅ¿t, the graces of ChriÅ¿t, or the vertue that floweth out of ChriÅ¿t onely: but I call the thing Å¿ignified, together with the benefites, and vertues flowing from him, the very Å¿ubÅ¿tance of ChriÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe, from which this vertue dooth flowe. The Å¿ubÅ¿tance, with the vertues, gifts, and graces, that flowe from the Å¿ubÅ¿tance,
is the thing Å¿ignified heere. As for the vertue and graces that flow from ChriÅ¿t, it is not poÅ¿sible that thou canÅ¿t be partaker of the vertue that floweth from his Å¿ubÅ¿tance, except thou be firÅ¿t partaker of the Å¿ubÅ¿tance it Å¿elfe. For how is it poÅ¿sible, that I can be partaker of the iuyce that floweth out of any Å¿ubÅ¿tance, except I be partaker of the Å¿ubÅ¿tance it Å¿elfe firÅ¿t?

Is it poÅ¿sible that my Å¿tomach can bee refreÅ¿hed with that meat, the Å¿ubÅ¿tance vvhereof came neuer in my mouth? Is it poÅ¿sible my drouth can be Å¿lackned with that drinke, that paÅ¿Å¿ed neuer downe my throat? Is it poÅ¿Å¿ible, that I can Å¿ucke any vertue out of anie thing, except I gette the Å¿ubÅ¿tance firÅ¿t? So it is impoÅ¿sible, that I can get the iuyce & vertue, that floweth out of ChriÅ¿t, except I get the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, that is himÅ¿elfe, firÅ¿t. So I call not the thing Å¿ignified, the grace, & vertue that floweth from ChriÅ¿t onelie; nor ChriÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe, and his Å¿ubÅ¿tance, without his vertue & graces onely; but ioyntly, the Å¿ubÅ¿tance with the graces, whole ChriÅ¿t,
God, and man, without Å¿eparation of his natures, without diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing of his Å¿ubÅ¿tance from his graces.

div.p:
WE ended the conÅ¿ideration of the Sacraments in generall, in our laÅ¿t ExerciÅ¿e, welbeloued in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us: now it remaines that we proceed, to the conÅ¿ideration of this Sacrament of the Lords Supper in particular. Now, FirÅ¿t head generall. we finde Å¿undry names giuen vnto the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, in the booke of God; and euery name carries a Å¿peciall reaÅ¿on with it. Of the names giueÌ vnto this Sacrament, both in the Bible, and by the ancients. Wee finde this Sacrament, called the body, and bloud of ChriÅ¿t. This name is giuen vnto it, no doubt, becauÅ¿e it is a heauenly, & Å¿piritual nouriture; it containes a nouriture of the Å¿oule, that is able to nouriÅ¿h, and traine vp the Å¿oule, to a life Å¿piritual, to that life euerlaÅ¿ting: for this cauÅ¿e it is called the body, & bloud of ChriÅ¿t. It is called alÅ¿o the Supper of the Lord, to put a difference betwixt
it, & a profane Å¿upper: for this is the Lords Supper, a holy Å¿upper; not a profane, or common Å¿upper: a Å¿upper, appointed for the increaÅ¿e of holineÅ¿s, for the food of the Å¿oule in holineÅ¿s, to feede the Å¿oule vnto life euerlaÅ¿ting. Not a Å¿upper appointed for the belly; for he had ended that Supper, that was appointed for the belly, or euer he began this Å¿upper, which was appointed for the Å¿oule. A Å¿upper, no doubt, hauing reÅ¿pect to the circuÌÅ¿tance of time, by reaÅ¿on it was inÅ¿tituted, in the article of that time, when they vÅ¿ed to Å¿uppe. It is called alÅ¿o in the Bible, The Table of the Lord. It is not called the Altar of the Lord: but the ApoÅ¿tle calleth it a Table, to Å¿it at; and not an Altar, to Å¿tand at: a Table, to take, and receiue at; & not an Altar, to offer at. It is called alÅ¿o, the Communion, and participation of the body, and bloud of ChriÅ¿t: we haue theÅ¿e names giuen vnto it, beÅ¿ide Å¿ome others, in the Scriptures of God. The Ancients of the Latine, & of the Greeke Churches, gaue it Å¿undry names, for Å¿undry reÅ¿pects. They called it, a publique action; and this vvas a very generall name. Some-times they called it a ThankÅ¿giuing. Some-times they called it

And at the laÅ¿t, in the declining eÅ¿tate of the Latine Church, & in the falling eÅ¿tate of the Romane Church, this Sacrament began to be peruerted; and with this decay, there came in a peruerÅ¿e name, and they called it the MaÅ¿Å¿e. They trouble themÅ¿elues much, concerning the deriuation of this name: Å¿ometime they Å¿eeke it from an Hebrew original; Å¿ometime from a Greeke; and Å¿ometime from a Latine originall: but it is plaine, that the vvord is deriued from the Latine; and it is a word which might haue been tollerable, when it was firÅ¿t inÅ¿tituted: for, no doubt, the Sacrament, at the firÅ¿t inÅ¿titution of this word, was not then wholly peruerted; but now, in proceÅ¿Å¿e of time, corruption hath preuatied Å¿o farre, that it hath turned the Sacrament into a Å¿acrifice; and where we Å¿hould take from the hand of GOD, in ChriÅ¿t, they make vs to giue.

This is plaine Idolatry: and therefore, vvhereas the vvord vvas tollerable before, now it ought not to be tollerable any way, it ought not to be Å¿uffered. And certainly, if wee had eaten, and drunke, as oft
the body & bloud of ChriÅ¿t in our Å¿oules, as wee haue eaten that bread, and drunke that wine, which are the Å¿ignes of his body and bloud, we would not haue Å¿uffered this word of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, much leÅ¿Å¿e the very action of it, to be Å¿o riÅ¿e in this Countrey: But becauÅ¿e we haue but played the counterfaits, and defrauded our Å¿oules of the body, and bloud of ChriÅ¿t, and tooke onely the outward Sacrament; therefore it is that our zeale decayeth; therfore it is, that our knowledge, and light decayeth: and for want of zeale, loue, and knowledge, the word of the MaÅ¿Å¿e, is becom cuÅ¿tomable vnto you, and not onely the word, but the very action. I will not runne out heerin: I onely tell you, what commeth of the abuÅ¿e of the hearing of the vvord, vvhat iudgements follow vpon the abuÅ¿e of the receiuing of the Sacraments.

Now, SecoÌd head generall. Of the ends why this Sacrament was inÅ¿tituted. I come to the ends wherefore the Sacrament was appointed. This Sacrament was inÅ¿tituted in the Å¿ignes of Bread, and Wine; and was appointed chiefely for this end, to repreÅ¿ent our Å¿pirituall nouriture, the full and perfect nouriture of our Å¿oules: that as he who hath Bread & Wine, lacketh nothing for the full nouriÅ¿hment

The Å¿econd end, wherfore this Sacrament was inÅ¿tituted, is this; That we might teÅ¿tifie to the world, and to the Princes of the world, who are enemies to our profeÅ¿sion; that we might openly avow, and teÅ¿tifie vnto them our Religion, and our manner of worÅ¿hipping, in the which we avow, and worÅ¿hip ChriÅ¿t: and that wee might alÅ¿o teÅ¿tifie our loue towards his members, our bretheren: this is the Å¿econd end vvherefore it was inÅ¿tituted. The third end, wherfore it was inÅ¿tituted, is this; to Å¿erue for our Å¿peciall comfort, and conÅ¿olation; to Å¿erue as a Å¿oueraine medicine, for all our Å¿pirituall diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, as wee finde our Å¿elues, either readie to fall, or prouoked to fall, by the diuell, the fleÅ¿h, or the world; or after that we haue fallen, and are put to flight by the diuell, and would faine flee away from God; GOD of his mercie, and of his infinite pitie, and bottomleÅ¿Å¿e

The fourth end, vvherefore this Sacrament was inÅ¿tituted, is this, that in this action, wee might thanke him for his benefites, and render to him hartie thanks, that he hath come downe Å¿o familiarly to vs, bowed the heauens, as it were and giuen vs the body and bloud of his owne Sonne, that wee might render vnto him harty thanks, and Å¿o Å¿anctifie his benefits vnto vs: for this thankÅ¿giuing, this Sacrament was alÅ¿o inÅ¿tituted. Thus far concerning the ends briefely.

Now, Third head generall. I come to the things contayned in this Sacrament. Yee Å¿ee with your eyes, there are corporall things, viÅ¿ible things, as the Bread, and Wine. There are againe hid from the eye of your body, but preÅ¿ent to the eye of your minde, Å¿pirituall things, heauenly, and invvard things: both theÅ¿e are in the Sacrament.

The corporal, viÅ¿ible, & outward things,

The Å¿pirituall thing in both the Sacraments,

The thing Å¿ignified, is, the Å¿ubÅ¿tance; that is, the body & bloud of ChriÅ¿t is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, out of which, this

Then I Å¿ay, Å¿uppoÅ¿e ChriÅ¿t, The thing Å¿ignified in both the SacrameÌts, is one: the Å¿ignes are not one. who is the thing Å¿ignified, remaine alwaies one, and the Å¿ame, in both the Sacraments: yet the Å¿ignes, whereby this one ChriÅ¿t is Å¿ignified in the Sacraments, are not one, nor of an â¢ quall number. There remaineth yet, concerning theÅ¿e Å¿ignes, two things to be inquired. div.p:

Now faith is a Å¿piritual thing: for fayth is the gift of God, poured downe into the heartes and mindes of men, and women, wrought in the Å¿oule of euery one, and that by the mightie working, and operation of the holy Å¿pirit. Ther were Å¿undry things obiected, againÅ¿t this kind of receiuing: I wil not inÅ¿iÅ¿t to repeat them: But beÅ¿ide all the obiections, which ye heard obiected, againÅ¿t this kind of Å¿piritual receiuing by faith; They Å¿ay, If ChriÅ¿t his fleÅ¿h, nor his blood, be not perceiued, nor receiued, but by the Å¿pirit, by

So they account faith, an imagination of the minde, a fantaÅ¿ie, and opinion, fleeting in the hearts of men: I cannot blame them, to think Å¿o of faith: For, as none can iudge of the Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿e of honnie, but they, that haue taÅ¿ted of it: So, there is none, can diÅ¿cerne, nor iudge of the nature of faith, but they that haue felt it, and raÅ¿ted in their hearts, what it is: And if they had taÅ¿ted, and felt in their Å¿oules, what faith brings with it; alas, they would not call that Å¿pirituall Iewell, and onely iewell of the Å¿oule, an imagination. They call it an imagination: and the ApoÅ¿tle deÅ¿cribing it, Heb. 11.1. calleth it a Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and a Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall ground: Marke how well theÅ¿e two agree, An Imagination, and a Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall ground. contrarie, the ApoÅ¿tle and they are, in the nature of faith. Vpon this they inferre, that as it is true in generall, hee can not be deliuered, nor giuen, but that Å¿ame way, that hee is receiued; and looke what way any thing is receiued, the Å¿ame way it is giuen, and deliuered: So (as they Å¿ay) hee being receiued by way of Imagination, hee is alÅ¿o in their fantaÅ¿ie, giuen and deliuered by way of Imagination. For if hee bee not giuen Å¿ay they, to thy hand, to thy mouth, nor to thy Å¿tomach corporally: hee cannot be giuen, but by an imagination, and fantaÅ¿ticall opinion. The reaÅ¿on that moueth them to thinke, that ChriÅ¿t cannot bee theirs, nor giuen to them truly in effect, and really, except he be giuen carnally, is this: That thing which is Å¿o far abÅ¿ent, and diÅ¿tant from vs, as the heauen is from the earth, cannot be Å¿aid to bee giuen to vs, nor to bee ours: But by your owne confesÅ¿ion, Å¿ay they to vs, ChriÅ¿t his bodie, is as farre abÅ¿ent from vs, as the heauen is, from the earth: Therefore ChriÅ¿t his bodie, nor his fleÅ¿h, cannot be giuen vnto vs, except by way of imagination, and Å¿o not truely, nor in effect: This argument,
framed in this Å¿orte, would at the firÅ¿t Å¿ight, Å¿eeme to be of Å¿ome force. But let vs examine the propoÅ¿ition of it: The propoÅ¿ition is this. That thing which is Å¿o farre abÅ¿ent from vs, as the beauen is from the earth, cannot be Å¿aid to be deliuered to vs, to be giuen to vs, or any waies to be ours.

Now whether is this propoÅ¿ition true or falÅ¿e? I Å¿ay this propoÅ¿ition is vntrue, and the contrarie moÅ¿t true. Will you aske of the Vbiquiter, if the true bodie of ChriÅ¿t be preÅ¿ent? hee will Å¿ay it is: will you aske, if it it be in, with, or vnder the bread? hee will anÅ¿were, it is in the bread, contentiuÃ¨, that is, the bread containes it: will you aske him, to what inÅ¿trument, it is offered? hee will anÅ¿were, that the bodie of ChriÅ¿t is offered, to the mouth of our bodie, and that the blood of ChriÅ¿t, is offered to the mouth of our bodie, as the PapiÅ¿ts doe: Will you knowe of vs, how ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us his true bodie, and blood is preÅ¿ent? wee will Å¿ay, that they are Å¿piritually preÅ¿ent, really preÅ¿ent, that is, preÅ¿ent in the Lords Supper, and not in the bread: wee will not Å¿ay, that his true fleÅ¿h is preÅ¿ent to the hand, or to the mouth of our bodies. But we Å¿ay it is Å¿piritually preÅ¿ent, that is, preÅ¿ent vnto thy Å¿pirit, and faythfull
Å¿oule: yea, euen as preÅ¿ent inwardlie, vnto thy Å¿oule, as the bread, and wine are preÅ¿ent vnto thy bodie, outwardly: Will you aske then, if the bodie, and blood of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, bee preÅ¿ent in the Lords Supper? Wee anÅ¿were in a word; They are preÅ¿ent, but not in the bread and wine, nor in the accidents, nor Å¿ubÅ¿tance of bread, and wine. And wee make ChriÅ¿t to be preÅ¿ent in this Sacrament, becauÅ¿e hee is preÅ¿ent to my Å¿oule, to my Å¿pirit, and fayth. AlÅ¿o, we make him preÅ¿ent in the Lords Supper, becauÅ¿e I haue him in his promiÅ¿e, This is my bodie; which promiÅ¿e, is preÅ¿ent to my fayth: and the nature of fayth is, to make things, that are abÅ¿ent in themÅ¿elues, yet preÅ¿ent: And therefore, Å¿eeing he is both preÅ¿ent, by fayth in his promiÅ¿e, & preÅ¿ent by the vertue of his holy Å¿pirit, who can Å¿ay, but that hee is preÅ¿ent in this Sacrament?

But yet the word would be explained, How a thing is Å¿aid to be preÅ¿ent and abÅ¿ent. what we mean by the word, preÅ¿ent, how a thing is Å¿aid to be preÅ¿ent, & abÅ¿ent. And knowing this, yee Å¿hall finde all the matter eaÅ¿ie. I Å¿ay, things are Å¿aid to be preÅ¿ent, as they are perceiued, by anie outward, or inward Å¿enÅ¿e, & as they are perceiued, by any
of the Å¿enÅ¿es, Å¿o are they preÅ¿ent, & the further they be perceiued the further preÅ¿ent: and by what Å¿enÅ¿e any thing is perceiued, to that Å¿enÅ¿e, it is preÅ¿ent: As if it bee outwardly perceiued, by an outward Å¿enÅ¿e, that thing is outwardly preÅ¿ent. As for example, if it be perceiued by the outward Å¿ight of the eye, by the outward hearing of the eare, by the outward feeling of the hands or taÅ¿te of the mouth, it is outwardly preÅ¿ent. Or if any thing be perceiued by the inward eye, by the inward taÅ¿te, & feeling of the Å¿oule, this thing can not be outwardly preÅ¿ent, but it muÅ¿t bee Å¿piritually, & inwardly preÅ¿ent to the Å¿oul: So I Å¿ay, euery thing is preÅ¿ent, as it is perceiued. So that if you perceiue not a thing outwardly, it is outwardly abÅ¿ent: and if ye perceiue not a thing inwardly, it is inwardly abÅ¿ent. It is not diÅ¿tance of place, that makes a thing abÅ¿ent, nor propinquitie of place that makes a thing preÅ¿ent: But it is onely the perceiuing of any thing, by any of thy Å¿enÅ¿es, that makes a thing preÅ¿ent; & the not perceiuing, that makes a thing abÅ¿ent: I Å¿ay, though the thing it Å¿elf were neuer Å¿o far diÅ¿taÌt, if thou perceiue it by thine outward Å¿enÅ¿e, it is preÅ¿ent vnto thee. As for example, my body,
and the Å¿unne are as farre diÅ¿tant in place, as the heauen is, from the earth; and yet this diÅ¿tance Å¿tayeth not the Å¿unnes preÅ¿ence from mee: why? BecauÅ¿e I perceiue the Å¿unne by mine eie, and other Å¿enÅ¿es; I feele it, and perceiue it by the heate, by the light, and by his brightneÅ¿Å¿e: So if a thing were neuer Å¿o farre diÅ¿tant, if wee haue Å¿enÅ¿es to perceiue the Å¿ame, it is preÅ¿ent to vs. Then the diÅ¿tance of place, makes not a thing abÅ¿ent from thee, if thou haÅ¿t Å¿enÅ¿es to perceiueit: likewiÅ¿e the neereneÅ¿Å¿e of place makes not a thing preÅ¿ent, be it neuer Å¿o neere, if thou haÅ¿t not Å¿enÅ¿es to perceiue it: As for example, if the Å¿unne Å¿hine vpon thine eyes, if thou bee blinde, it is not preÅ¿ent to thee, becauÅ¿e thou canÅ¿t not perceiue it. A Å¿weete tune will neuer be preÅ¿ent to a deafe eare, though it be Å¿ung in the eare of that man, becauÅ¿e hee hath not a Å¿enÅ¿e to perceiue it: And a well told tale, will neuer bee preÅ¿ent to a foole, becauÅ¿e hee cannot vnderÅ¿tand it, nor hath no iudgement to perceiue it: So it is not the neereneÅ¿Å¿e, nor diÅ¿tance of place, that maketh any thing preÅ¿ent, or abÅ¿ent, but only the perceiuing, or not perceiuing of it.

Now the word being made cleere, How the bodie of ChriÅ¿t is preÅ¿ent. aske you, how the bodie of ChriÅ¿t is preÅ¿ent? To giue our iudgement in a word, as yee haue heard from time to time, hee is preÅ¿ent, not to the outward Å¿enÅ¿es, but to the inward Å¿enÅ¿es, which is fayth, wrought in the Å¿oule. For this action of the Sacrament, and of the Lords Supper, is partly corporall, and partly Å¿pirituall: I call this action, partly corporall, not in reÅ¿pect onely, that the obiects, that is, That bread, and that wine, are corporall, but alÅ¿o in reÅ¿pect, my mouth, whereunto theÅ¿e things are offered, the inÅ¿trument whereby, and the manner how, theÅ¿e things are receiued, are all corporal, and naturall: I call the Å¿ame action againe, partly Å¿pirituall, not onely in reÅ¿pect of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, who is the heauenly, and Å¿pirituall thing of the Sacrament, but alÅ¿o in reÅ¿pect of my Å¿oule, whereunto, Chr. is offered, and giuen, in reÅ¿pect the inÅ¿trument whereby, and the manner how, hee is receiued, are all Å¿pirituall: for I get not ChriÅ¿t corporally, but Å¿piritually: So in theÅ¿e reÅ¿pect, I call this action, partly corporall, and partly Å¿pirituall.

Now, confounde not theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of
actions, The corporall, and naturall Å¿ignes, with the Å¿pirituall thing, Å¿ignified thereby: againe, confound not the mouth of the bodie, with the mouth of the Å¿oule. Thirdly, confound not the outwarde manner of receuing, by the hand of the bodie, with the Å¿pirituall manner of receiuing, by the hand of the Å¿oule: And Å¿o it Å¿hall bee exceeding cleere to Å¿ee, that each thing Å¿hall bee preÅ¿ent, to the owne inÅ¿trument; that is, The bodie of ChriÅ¿t, which is the Å¿pirituall thing Å¿ignified, Å¿hall be preÅ¿ent to the Å¿pirituall mouth, and hand: and the bread, and wine, which are the corporall Å¿ignes, are preÅ¿ent to the corporall mouth and hand. Then how is any obiect preÅ¿ent? A corporall obiect, is corporally preÅ¿ent: and an inward obiect, is inwardly preÅ¿ent. Of what nature is the thing Å¿ignified? It is of an heauenly nature. Then aske you, how is he preÅ¿ent; He is Å¿piritually, and heauenly preÅ¿ent to the Å¿oule, and the mouth of the Å¿oule, which is faith, For it were a prepoÅ¿terous thing, to make the thing Å¿ignified preÅ¿ent to thy belly, or to the mouth or eye of thy body; for if that were Å¿o, it Å¿hould not be Å¿piritually preÅ¿ent: becauÅ¿e euery thing is preÅ¿ent as it agreeth in it owne nature. Is it a bodily thing? it is
bodily preÅ¿ent: & if it be a heauenly thing, it is Å¿piritually preÅ¿ent: So I thinke no man can doubt, how the bodie of ChriÅ¿t is preÅ¿ent: hee is not carnally preÅ¿ent, but Å¿piritually preÅ¿ent to my Å¿oule, and to faith, in my Å¿oule: Thus far concerning the manner of his preÅ¿ence.

Now the laÅ¿t part of our difference is this: The laÅ¿t point in controuerÅ¿ie betwixt vs, and the PapiÅ¿ts. wee haue to conÅ¿ider to whom the words ought to be directed, & pronounced: For we & the PapiÅ¿ts differ in this laÅ¿t point; we Å¿ay, that the words ought to be directed, & pronounced vnto the people, to the faithfull communicants. They on the contrary Å¿ay, that the words ought not to be directed, nor pronounced to the people, but to the elements, & not to be cleerly pronounced, but whiÅ¿pered on the elements; So that if they be Å¿poken to the people, or Å¿poken openly, their charme auailes not. Now, I Å¿ay, that as this holy action, is peruerted by them in all the reÅ¿t, Å¿o they peruert it in this point alÅ¿o, in Å¿peaking that, to the dumbe elements, which they Å¿hould Å¿peak to the people of God: For, I Å¿hall proue it cleerely, by three arguments taken out of the Scriptures, that the words ought not to be Å¿poken, to the bread, but to the people of God.

And firÅ¿t I Å¿ay, The promiÅ¿es of mercie and grace, ought to be directed, and pronounced to them, in whom the Lord performs them, & makes them effectual: But Å¿o it is, That the promiÅ¿es of mercie and grace, are performed, and made effectuall, not in bread, and wine, but in faythfull men & women: Therefore theÅ¿e promiÅ¿es Å¿hould be directed, to faythfull men & women. Now here is the promiÅ¿e of mercy & grace: This is my bodie which is broken for you: and this promiÅ¿e is made to no other thing, but to the faithfull, and Å¿o to them onely, it ought to bee directed. Secondly, wee haue to conÅ¿ider, That this Sacrament, Å¿eales vp a couenant of grace, and mercie. Now, with whom will God make his couenant of mercy, and grace? will hee make a couenant with a peece of bread, or any dumbe element: There is no man will enter into couenant with his Å¿eruant; much leÅ¿Å¿e, will enter into couenant with a dumbe element: So in reÅ¿pect this Sacrament Å¿eales vp a couenant, this couenant, of necesÅ¿itie, muÅ¿t bee made with a faithfull Å¿oule, and in no wiÅ¿e with the dumbe element: and therefore, theÅ¿e wordes cannot bee directed to the
elements. Thirdly, looke to the end wherfore this Sacrament vvas appointed. Is it not to lead vs to ChriÅ¿t? Is it not to nouriÅ¿h my faith in ChriÅ¿t? Is it not to nouriÅ¿h me in a conÅ¿tant perÅ¿waÅ¿ion, of the Lords mercy in ChriÅ¿t? Was this Sacrament appointed to make the elements, Gods? No: for if ye marke Gods purpoÅ¿e in this inÅ¿titution, yee Å¿hall finde, that ChriÅ¿t hath not ordained this inÅ¿titution, to nobilitate the Elements, to fauour and reÅ¿pect the Elements, which were Bread, and Wine, yeÅ¿terday, to be Gods to day. Wee on the contrary, Å¿ay plainely, that the inÅ¿titution of ChriÅ¿t, reÅ¿pecteth not the elements, to alter their nature. Indeed, it is appointed to alter vs, to change vs, and to make vs more and more Å¿pirituall, and to Å¿anctifie the elements to our vÅ¿e. But the Å¿peciall end, is this, To make vs holie, and more & more to growe vp, in a Å¿ure faith in ChriÅ¿t, and not to alter the Elements, nor to make them gods. And therefore, by all theÅ¿e three Arguments, it is euident, that the words ought not to be directed to the Elements, but to the people, and faithfull Communicants.

Now, to come to an end: There is one
thing, ConcluÅ¿ion, with an exhortatioÌ. without the which wee cannot profit, let vs diÅ¿courÅ¿e neuer Å¿o long vpon the right vnderÅ¿tanding of the Sacrament. Ye Å¿ee now, how all that is Å¿poken concerning the Sacrament, is grounded, and dependeth vpon faith. Let a man haue faith, be it neuer Å¿o little, hee Å¿hall get Å¿ome hold of ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿ome inÅ¿ight, in the vnderÅ¿tanding of this Sacrament: but wanting faith, though a man endeuour himÅ¿elfe to make the Sacraments neuer Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible, it is not poÅ¿sible that hee can gette any hold of ChriÅ¿t, or any inÅ¿ight of him. For, without faith, we cannot be ChriÅ¿tians: we can neither get a Å¿ight of God, nor feele God in ChriÅ¿t, without faith.

Faith is the onely thing, that tranÅ¿lates our Å¿oules, out of that death and damnation vvherein vvee vvere conceiued and borne, and planteth life in vs. So, the vvhole Å¿tudie, and endeuour of a ChriÅ¿tian, Å¿hould tend to this; To craue, that the Lord in his mercie, vvould illuminate his minde vvith the eye of faith, and that hee would kindle in his heart, a loue of faith, and vvorke in his hart, a thirÅ¿t, and deÅ¿ire of the obiect of faith, & more and more, to thirÅ¿t, and hunger, for the
foode of faith, that nouriÅ¿hes vs to life eternall.

Without this faith, (hovv-Å¿oeuer the naturall man, vnderÅ¿tanding naturally, would flatter himÅ¿elfe) Å¿urely, there is no bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e; but all his life is more then terrible miÅ¿ery. For, what-Å¿oeuer it be that flatters, and pleaÅ¿eth thee now, be it a thought, or motion of the minde, or an action of the body, that pleaÅ¿eth thee now, without faith; the Å¿ame very motion, cogitation, or action, Å¿hall torment thee heereafter.

So, vvithout faith, it is not poÅ¿sible to pleaÅ¿e GOD; and vvhatÅ¿oeuer pleaÅ¿eth not GOD, is done to torment thee: Therefore craue mercie, for whatÅ¿oeuer motion, cogitation, or action, vvherein thou haÅ¿t offended GOD; or, for the Å¿ame, God Å¿hall offend, and torment thee. And to eÅ¿chevv the offence of God, there is no meanes, but by true faith; therefore the Å¿tudie of a ChriÅ¿tian Å¿hould be, to grow in faith.

Now, by hearing of the vvord, thou getteÅ¿t faith; and by receiuing this Sacrament, thou obtaineÅ¿t the increaÅ¿e of faith; and hauing faith, the receiuing of the Sacrament
Å¿hall be fruitfull: but, vvithout faith, thou eateÅ¿t thineowne condemnation. Then the whole Å¿tudy of a ChriÅ¿tian is, to get faith; and this faith cannot be obtained with idleneÅ¿Å¿e, but by earneÅ¿t prayer: therefore, let euery one of vs fall downe, and craue earneÅ¿tly this faith, and the increaÅ¿e of it, whereby we may be worthy Receiuers of this bleÅ¿Å¿ed Sacrament; and that for the righteous merits of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. To whom, with the Father, and the holy Spirit, be all honour, praiÅ¿e, and glory, both now, and euer, Amen.

div.head: THE FOVRTH Sermon, vpon the preparation to the Lords Supper.

epigraph.q: Let euery man therefore examine himÅ¿elfe, and Å¿o let him eate of this Bread, and drinke of this Cup.

div.p:
THough the doctrine of our triall, and due examination (well-beloued in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us) ought to goe before the doctrine, and receiuing of the Sacrament: yet notwithÅ¿tanding, Å¿eeing that preparation is alwaies, at all times, as well neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the hearing of the Å¿imple word, as for the receiuing of the viÅ¿ible Sacrament; (for no man can heare the word of God fruitfully, except in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure he prepare his Å¿oule, and prepare the eares of his hart, how to hear) therefore the doctrine of preparation, and due examination, muÅ¿t come in it ovvne
place, and be very neceÅ¿Å¿ary for cuery one of you. The ApoÅ¿tle, in the words vvhich we haue read, deliuereth his counÅ¿aile, and giueth his aduiÅ¿e; and not onely giues his aduiÅ¿e, but giues his admonition, and commaund, That we Å¿hould not come to the Table of the Lord, That we Å¿hould not come to the hearing of the word, raÅ¿hly: but that euery one of vs, Å¿hould come to this holy worke, with reuerence; that wee Å¿hould prepare, and Å¿anctifie our Å¿elues in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure. And Å¿eeing we go vnto the King of heauens Table, it becomes vs to put on our beÅ¿t array. In a word, hee deliuereth the whole doctrine, and matter of this preparation, when he Å¿aith; Let euery man, and let euery woman, try and examine themÅ¿elues. As if he would Å¿ay, Let euery one of you, try and examine your Å¿oules. That is, try the eÅ¿tate of your owne harts, and condition of your owne conÅ¿ciences. Marke and behold, in vvhat eÅ¿tate you heart is with GOD, and in what eÅ¿tate your conÅ¿cience is with your neighbour.

He bids not your neighbour to try you, hee bids not your companion to try your hart; but he biddes your Å¿elfe, in perÅ¿on, to try your owne conÅ¿cience; hee biddes
your Å¿elfe, try your owne hart; becauÅ¿e none can be certaine of the eÅ¿tate of your hart, or of the condition of your conÅ¿cience, but your Å¿elfe.

Now, he excludes not others from the tryall of you neither (for it is lawfull for the PaÅ¿tor to try you) but others cannot try you Å¿o narrowly, as ye your Å¿elues may; for no man can know Å¿o much of mee, as I know of my Å¿elfe. No man can be certaine of the eÅ¿tate of your hart, and condition of your conÅ¿cience; & yet you your Å¿elues may be certaine of it. As for others, men may iudge of your hart, and conÅ¿cience, according to your works, and effects; and except your works & effects bee very wicked, and altogether vitious, we are bound in conÅ¿cience, to iudge charitably of your harts and conÅ¿ciences. Therefore, there is none Å¿o meet to try the Å¿pirit of a man, to try the hart, or conÅ¿cience of a man, as is the man himÅ¿elfe.

Now, The heads to be intreated in this Sermons. that this tryall may be the better made, ye haue firÅ¿t to vnderÅ¿tand what it is that ye Å¿hould try: What ye call a conÅ¿cience, which the ApoÅ¿t. commands you to try. Next, ye are to conÅ¿ider, for what reaÅ¿ons & cauÅ¿es ye Å¿hold try your coÌÅ¿ciences.

Thirdly, and laÅ¿t of all; ye are to knowe in what chiefe points yee Å¿hould try, and examine your conÅ¿ciences. Then, that wee Å¿peake not vnto you of things vnknowen, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for euery one of you (Å¿eeing there is none of you that lacketh a conÅ¿cience) to vnderÅ¿tand what a conÅ¿cience is: and as neerely as GOD Å¿hall giue mee grace, I will bring you to the vnderÅ¿tanding, and knowledge of a conÅ¿cience.

I call a conÅ¿cience, Definition of conÅ¿cience, with the expoÅ¿ition of the paits therof. a certaine feeling in the hart, reÅ¿embling the iudgement of the liuing GOD, following vpon a deed done by vs, flowing from a knowledge in the minde, accompanied with a certaine motion in the hart, to wit, feare, or ioy, trembling, or reioycing. Now, we will examine the parts of this definition. I call it firÅ¿t of all, a certaine feeling in the hart; for, the Lord hath left Å¿uch a Å¿tampe in the hart of euery man, that he doth not that thing Å¿o Å¿ecretly, nor Å¿o quietly, but hee makes his owne hart to Å¿mite him, and to Å¿trike him: hee makes him to feele in his owne hart, whether he hath done well, or ill.

The Lord hath placed this feeling in the hart; why? BecauÅ¿e the eyes of God, looke not Å¿o much vpon the outward countenance,
and exterior behauiour, as vpon the inward hart. For he Å¿aith to Samuel, in the firÅ¿t booke, 16.7. The Lord beholds the hart. So, 1. Chron. 28.9. hee Å¿aith to Salomon, The Lord Å¿earcheth all harts, and vnderÅ¿tands all imaginations, and thoughts. AlÅ¿o Ieremy 11.20. The Lord tries the reins and the hart. And the ApoÅ¿tle, 1. Cor. 4.5. Å¿aith, The Lord Å¿hall lighten things that are hid in darknes, and make the counÅ¿els of the hart manifeÅ¿t. So, in reÅ¿pect that the Lord will chiefely haue to doe with the heart, therefore in the hart hee placeth this feeling, which is the chiefe part of conÅ¿cience.

I Å¿ay next, that this feeling reÅ¿embleth the iudgement of God: for, this feeling was left, and placed in our Å¿oules for this end and purpoÅ¿e, that we might haue a domeÅ¿ticall, and familiar iudgement within our Å¿elues, to reÅ¿emble, and deÅ¿cribe, the Å¿ecret, and inuiÅ¿ible iudgement of the high God; A particular iudgement, to goe before that generall iudgement, in that generall and great day, where euery man Å¿hal be iuÅ¿tified, or condemned, according to the particular iudgement, that is within his owne conÅ¿cience. In the meane time,
this conÅ¿cience is left in vs, to arreÅ¿t vs in this life; thereby, as it were, to eaÅ¿e the liuing God, at that laÅ¿t Iudgement. For the bookes of our own conÅ¿ciences, in that laÅ¿t day Å¿hal be opened; & euery man Å¿hal receiue, according to the report of the decree that is within his ovvne conÅ¿cience: therefore I Å¿ay, that our conÅ¿cience reÅ¿embles the iudgement of GOD.

The third thing that I Å¿ay, is this; It followeth vpon a deed done by vs: our conÅ¿cience, nor our hart Å¿trikes vs not, before the deede be done; our hart Å¿trikes vs not, before the euill deed be committed: no, it goes not before the deed; but the Å¿troke of the conÅ¿cience, and feeling of the hart, followes immediatly vpon the deed, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that the deed is no Å¿ooner done by thee, but thy conÅ¿cience applyes it to thy Å¿elf, and giues out the Å¿entence againÅ¿t thy Å¿elfe: therefore, I Å¿ay, It is a feeling, following vpon a deede done by vs.

And next I Å¿ay, flowing from a knowledge in the minde; for except the conÅ¿cience haue information, and except the heart knovve, that the deede vvhich is done, is euill; the hart, nor the conÅ¿cience can neuer count it to be euill: therefore
knowledge muÅ¿t goe before the Å¿troke of the conÅ¿cience: thy hart can neuer feele that to be euill, which thy minde knoweth not to be euill.

So, knowledge muÅ¿t euer goe before feeling, and according to the meaÅ¿ure of thy knowledge, according to the nature, and qualitie of thy knowledge, accordingly Å¿hall the teÅ¿timonie and Å¿troke of thy conÅ¿cience be. For a light knowledge, a doubting, and vncertaine knowledge, makes a light, and Å¿mall Å¿troke: as on the other part, a holy and Å¿olid knowledge, drawne out of the word of God, maketh a heauy Å¿troke of the conÅ¿cience. So the conÅ¿cience muÅ¿t anÅ¿were to the knovvledge. If we haue no other knowledge, but the knowledge which wee haue by nature, and by the light & Å¿parks which are left in nature, our conÅ¿cience will anÅ¿wer no further, but to that knowledge: but if beÅ¿ide the light of nature, we haue a knowledge of God in his word, & a knowledge of God by his holy Å¿pirit, working in our harts; our coÅ¿ciences wil then go further, & excuÅ¿e, or accuÅ¿e vs, according vnto the light that is in the word. So that the conÅ¿cience is not acquired, or obtained, at what time we are
enlightened, by the working of the holie Spirit, and hearing of the word of GOD: but, our conÅ¿cience is borne with vs, is naturall to vs, and is left in the Å¿oule of euery man & woman: & as there are Å¿ome Å¿parks of light left in nature, Å¿o there is a conÅ¿cience left in it; and if there were no more, that Å¿ame light that is left in thy nature, Å¿hall be enough to condemne thee. So, the conÅ¿cience is not gotten, or begun at the hearing of the word, or at that time, when we begin to reforme our Å¿elues, by the aÅ¿siÅ¿tance, and renuing of the holy Spirit: but euery man by nature hath a conÅ¿cience, & the Lord hath left it in our nature; and except that this conÅ¿cience be reformed, according to the word of God, that Å¿ame naturall conÅ¿cience Å¿hall be enough to condemne thee eternally: therefore, I Å¿ay, flowing from a knowledge of the minde. LaÅ¿t of all, I Å¿ay, accompanied with a certaine motion of the hart: and wee expreÅ¿Å¿e this motion, in feare, or ioy, trembling, or reioycing. In very great feare, if the deede be exceeding heynous, and the Å¿troke of the conÅ¿cience be very heauy; then the conÅ¿cience neuer taketh reÅ¿t, for guiltineÅ¿Å¿e will euer dread. But if the deede be
honeÅ¿t, godly, and commendable, it maketh a glad hart, and maketh the hart euen to burÅ¿t out into ioy. So, to bee Å¿hort in this matter (for I purpoÅ¿e not to make a common place of it) yee Å¿ee, that in euerie conÅ¿cience, there muÅ¿t be two things: FirÅ¿t, there muÅ¿t be a knowledge; & next, there muÅ¿t be a feeling: whereby, according to thy knowledge, thou applyeÅ¿t vnto thine owne hart, the deed done by thee. Then, except the hart will do his part, as the mind doth his part, the whole Å¿oule is not conÅ¿ecrate to God: for God hath not made the Å¿oule, that the hart Å¿hould Å¿erue thee, and the mind only Å¿hold Å¿erue him; but thy Å¿eruice is then only acceptable to God, when
thou conÅ¿ecrateÅ¿t thy hart, as well as thy minde to him.

Now, A Å¿imilitude of the apprehenÅ¿ion of the corporall foode, to illuÅ¿trate the Å¿pirituall. this matter is Å¿o cleare, that it needeth not to be illuÅ¿trated by Å¿imilitude: yet to make it more plaine vnto you, I vvill Å¿hew you by a Å¿imilitude, that the apprehenÅ¿ion of the minde is not enough, except yee get the apprehenÅ¿ion of the hart alÅ¿o. In corporall things, in meat & drink, which Å¿erue for the vÅ¿e of your bodies, there muÅ¿t be of this meat and drinke, two Å¿orts of apprehenÅ¿ions: and as there is two Å¿orts of apprehenÅ¿ion, of the meat and drinke, that is the foode of the body: Å¿o there is two Å¿orts of apprehenÅ¿ion of the body, and bloud of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, which is our meate and drinke Å¿pirituall. Of meat and drinke corporall, there is an apprehenÅ¿ion by the eye, and by the taÅ¿te: that while the meate is preÅ¿ent vnto you on the Table, your eye taketh a view of that meat, diÅ¿cerneth it, and maketh choice of it: and not onely the eye, but alÅ¿o the taÅ¿te diÅ¿cerneth the meat, and the taÅ¿te approouing it, that is called the firÅ¿t apprehenÅ¿ion.

Now, vpon this which is the firÅ¿t, the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion followeth: that is, after
that ye haue chewed that meat, Å¿wallowed it, & Å¿ent it to your Å¿tomack, where it digeÅ¿teth, and conuerteth into your nouriture; then in your Å¿tomack, ye get the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion. But if your eye like not that meat, neither your taÅ¿te like it, the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion followeth not; for thou wilt Å¿pet it out againe, or reiect it, preferring Å¿ome other meat vnto it, that thou likeÅ¿t better. That meat which thou likeÅ¿t not, enters neuer into thy Å¿tomack, and Å¿o it can neuer be conuerted into thy nouriÅ¿hment: for, it is onely the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion of the meat, that is the cauÅ¿e of the nouriÅ¿hment of the body, in our corporall foode; Å¿o that if yee chew not this meat, and Å¿wallow it, it feeds you not; then it is onely the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion that nouriÅ¿heth our bodies.

It is euen Å¿o in Å¿pirituall things (Å¿o farre as they may be compared) in the foode of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, who is the life, and nouriture of our Å¿oules and conÅ¿ciences. There muÅ¿t be two Å¿orts of apprehenÅ¿ion of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. The firÅ¿t apprehenÅ¿ion is, by the eye of the minde; that is, by our knowledge, & vnderÅ¿tanding: for, as the eye of the body, diÅ¿cerneth by an outward light; Å¿o the
eye of the minde, diÅ¿cerneth by an inward, and renewed vnderÅ¿tanding, whereby wee get the firÅ¿t apprehenÅ¿ion of ChriÅ¿t.

Now, if this firÅ¿t apprehenÅ¿ion of ChriÅ¿t like vs well, then the next followeth: Wee beginne to caÅ¿t the affection of our harts on him; we haue good will to him: for all our affections proceed from our will, and our affections beeing renewed, and made holy, wee Å¿ette them wholly vpon ChriÅ¿t. We loue him; and if we loue him, we take hold on him, we eate him, and digeÅ¿t him; that is, we apply him to our Å¿oules: and Å¿o, of this loue, and liking of him, the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion doth follow. But if we haue no will to him, if wee haue no loue, nor liking of him, what doe we? Then we reiect him, and preferre our owne Idol, and the Å¿eruice of our own affections, to him; and Å¿o the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion followeth not. Wee cannot digeÅ¿t him; and if wee digeÅ¿t him not, that Å¿pirituall life cannot growe in vs: for marke, in vvhat place the eye Å¿erues to the bodie, in the Å¿ame roome, Å¿erueth knowledge, and vnderÅ¿tanding to thy Å¿oule: and looke in vvhat place, thy hand, and thy mouth, thy taÅ¿te, and thy Å¿tomack, Å¿erue vnto thy body, in that
very place, Å¿erue the hart, and affections to thy Å¿oule.

So that, as our bodies cannot be nouriÅ¿hed, except our hands take, and our mouthes eate the meate, whereby the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion may follow: likewiÅ¿e, our Å¿oules cannot feede on ChriÅ¿t, except we hold him, and imbrace him hartilie, by our wills, and affections. For we come not to ChriÅ¿t, by any outward motion of our bodies, but by an inward motion, and apprehenÅ¿ion of the hart. For God finding vs all in a reprobate Å¿enÅ¿e, he brings vs to ChriÅ¿t, by reforming the affection of our Å¿oules, by making vs to loue him. And therefore, the Å¿econd apprehenÅ¿ion, wherby wee digeÅ¿t our Sauiour, will neuer enter into our Å¿oules, except, as hee pleaÅ¿eth the eye, Å¿o he pleaÅ¿e the will, and the affection alÅ¿o.

Now, if this come to paÅ¿Å¿e, that our wills & affections, are wholly bent vpon ChriÅ¿t; then, no doubt, vvee haue gotten this Iewell of faith. Haue yee Å¿uch a liking in your minds, and Å¿uch a loue in your harts of ChriÅ¿t, that ye will prefer him, before all things in the world? then, no queÅ¿tion, faith is begun in you.

Now, How faith is nouriÅ¿hed and entertained in vs. after a thing is begunne, there is yet more required: for though this faith be formed in your mindes, in your harts, and Å¿oules, yet that is not enough; but that which is formed, muÅ¿t be nouriÅ¿hed; and hee who is conceiued, muÅ¿t be entertained and brought vp: or elÅ¿e, the loue that is begunne in mee, by the holy Å¿pirit, except by ordinary meanes it be daily entertained and nouriÅ¿hed, it will decay: except the Lord continue the working of his holie Spirit, it is not poÅ¿sible that I can continue in the faith.

And how muÅ¿t we nouriÅ¿h, and continue faith in our Å¿oules? Two manner of waies. FirÅ¿t, wee nouriÅ¿h faith begunne in our Å¿oules, by hearing of the word; not of euerie word, but by hearing of the vvord of God preached: and not by hearing of euery man, but by hearing the word preached by him that is Å¿ent. For this is the ordinarie means wherunto the Lord hath bound himÅ¿elfe; hee will work faith, by the hearing of the word, and the receiuing of the Sacraments. And the more that thou heareÅ¿t the vvord, and the oftner that thou receiueÅ¿t the Sacraments, the more thy faith is nouriÅ¿hed.

Now, it is not onely by hearing of the word, & receiuing of the Sacraments, that we nouriÅ¿h faith. The word, and the Sacraments, are not able of themÅ¿elues to nouriÅ¿h this faith in vs, except the working of the holy Spirit be conioyned vvith their miniÅ¿tery. But the word, and the Sacraments, are Å¿aid to nouriÅ¿h faith in our Å¿oules, becauÅ¿e they offer, and exhibite ChriÅ¿t vnto vs, who is the meat, the drink, and life of our Å¿oules: and in reÅ¿pect that in the word and Sacraments, wee get ChriÅ¿t, who is the foode of our Å¿oules, therefore the word and Sacraments, are Å¿aid to nouriÅ¿h our Å¿oules. As it is Å¿aid, Acts 2.42. The DiÅ¿ciples of ChriÅ¿t, continued in the ApoÅ¿tles doctrine, and fellowÅ¿hippe, and breaking of bread, and prayers; by theÅ¿e means, entertaining, augmenting, and nouriÅ¿hing the faith that was begunne in them. Then the holy Spirit begets this faith, works this faith, creates this faith, nouriÅ¿heth, and entertaineth this faith in our Å¿oules, by hearing of the word preached, and by the receiuing of the Sacraments: which are the ordinary meanes, whereby the Lord nouriÅ¿heth vs, and continueth this Å¿pirituall foode with vs. For, obÅ¿erue
by what meanes the Å¿pirituall life is begun, by the Å¿ame meanes, it is nouriÅ¿hed, and entertained; as this temporall life is entertained and nouriÅ¿hed, by the Å¿ame meanes, whereby it is begun.

Then Å¿eeing by theÅ¿e meanes, ConcluÅ¿ion, with an exhortatioÌ. the holy Spirit begets this vvorke of faith in our Å¿oules: It is our dutie to craue, that hee would continue the worke which hee hath begunne. And for this cauÅ¿e, we Å¿hould reÅ¿ort to the hearing of the vvord, when it is preached, and to the receiuing of the Sacraments, when they are miniÅ¿tred, that we may be fedde in our Å¿oules to life euerlaÅ¿ting.

But alas, wee are come to Å¿uch a loathing diÅ¿daine, or reiecting of heauenly foode in this Countrey, that where men in the beginning, would haue gone, Å¿ome twentie miles, Å¿ome fortie miles, to the hearing of this vvord: they vvill Å¿carcelie novv, come from their houÅ¿es, to the Church, and remaine there but one houre to heare the vvord, but rather abide at home. VVell, I Å¿ay, too much vvealth vvith-drawes their hearts; and the aboundance of this vvord, ingenders Å¿uch a loathÅ¿omneÅ¿Å¿e, that it is a rare thing to
finde out any, that haue that thirÅ¿t, and deÅ¿ire to heare the vvord, as they vvere wont to haue in the beginning.

And for thoÅ¿e that are in higher places, they will heare it Å¿ildome, or not at all: for they cannot indure to heare the thing that accuÅ¿eth them, and conuicts them, and therefore they auoyde it. But they Å¿hould not doe Å¿o, they Å¿hould not Å¿hunne ChriÅ¿t, nor abÅ¿taine from â¢ is vvord that accuÅ¿eth them: but they Å¿hould heare the vvord; and as the vvord accuÅ¿eth them, they Å¿hould accuÅ¿e themÅ¿elues alÅ¿o; that thereby, they may come to a confeÅ¿sion of their Å¿inne, and obtaine mercy for the Å¿ame.

So, vvhen ChriÅ¿t accuÅ¿eth thee, thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t not runne from him; but thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t draw neere to him; thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t threaten kindneÅ¿Å¿e of him, and, as it vvere, make a breach, and forcible entry into his kingdome. It is not the way, vvhen thy Å¿innes touch thee, and when ChriÅ¿t accuÅ¿eth thee, to runne from him: no, thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t then turne to him, thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e thy Å¿inne, cry Peccaui, and Å¿eeke mercy: and after that thou haÅ¿t obtained mercy, this word Å¿hal becom
as pleaÅ¿ant to thee, and thou Å¿halt take as great delight to come to the hearing of it, as euer thou delightedÅ¿t to flie from it before. But alas! our lothÅ¿omneÅ¿Å¿e and diÅ¿daine is growen to Å¿uch an height, that truly, I am moued to belieue firmly, that the Lord hath concluded, that we Å¿hal not enter into his reÅ¿t, & that onely for the great contempt of his mercy, and grace, which is now Å¿o richly offred. For why? God can not deale otherwiÅ¿e with vs, then hee dealt with our fore-fathers, the IÅ¿raelites, for the negligence of his vvord, vvhich was but then obÅ¿curely preached: for then it was farre from the incarnation of ChriÅ¿t; and the farther that it was from his incarnation, the vvord was euer the more obÅ¿curely preached, vnder darke types, and Å¿hadowes. Yet notvvithÅ¿tanding, the Fathers that heard that word preached, and belieued it not, they periÅ¿hed all in the WilderneÅ¿Å¿e, except two; as ye haue Å¿ometime heard out of this place.

And if they, for the contempt of Å¿o dark a light periÅ¿hed: much more muÅ¿t yee, that are their children periÅ¿h, for the contempt of the Å¿unne of righteouÅ¿nes, who is riÅ¿en Å¿o plainely, and Å¿hineth Å¿o cleerely
now, in the preaching of the GoÅ¿pell; except the Lord in his mercy preuent you; and except ye preuent his Iudgements, by earneÅ¿t Å¿eeking; and except ye Å¿eeke a feeling, and Å¿eeke inward Å¿enÅ¿es, that ye may Å¿ee, & feele, the grace that is offered; craue againe, that he will Å¿anctifie your harts by repentance, that yee may repent you of your Å¿innes, and lead an honeÅ¿t, & a godly conuerÅ¿ation, in all time to come; that both body and Å¿oule may be Å¿aued in the great day of the Lord. The Lord worke this in your Å¿oules, that ye may Å¿eeke mercie; and Å¿eeking mercy, yee may obtaine mercy; and in mercy, ye may lay hold on ChriÅ¿t, and that for his righteous merits. To whom, with the Father, and the holie GhoÅ¿t, be all honour, praiÅ¿e, and glorie, both now, and euer. Amen.

div.head: THE FIFT AND last Sermon, vpon the preparation to the Lords Supper.

epigraph.q: Let euery man therefore, examine himÅ¿elfe; and Å¿o let him eate of this Bread, and drinke of this Cup, &c.

div.p:
To the end that ye may goe forward, & proceed in the worke of this triall, with the better Å¿peed, and with the better fruits; in this examination, we laid down this order. FirÅ¿t of all, I Å¿hewed, what that is which we call a conÅ¿cience, and what is meant thereby. Next, I declared, for what cauÅ¿es yee Å¿hould put your conÅ¿ciences to this triall, and narrow examination. And thirdlie, Å¿o farre as time Å¿uffered, I entred into the points, wherein euery one of you Å¿hould try, and examine your owne conÅ¿ciences. As for conÅ¿cience, that yee may call that definition to your memory, I will reÅ¿ume it Å¿hortlie. We call a conÅ¿cience, a certain feeling in the hart, reÅ¿embling the righteous Iudgement of GOD, following vpon a deed done by vs, flowing froÌ a knowledge in the mind. A feeling, accompanied with a motion in the hart; a motion, either of feare, or ioy, trembling, or reioycing. I leaue the opening vp of theÅ¿e parts, to
your memories, and I pray God, that they may be well Å¿anctified. I come next, to the cauÅ¿es, wherefore euerie one of you Å¿hould bee carefull in trying, and examining your owne conÅ¿ciences. The firÅ¿t cauÅ¿e is, becauÅ¿e the Lord of heauen, hath his eye continually vpon the conÅ¿cience: the eye of God, is neuer from the conÅ¿cience, and heart of man, as I proued to you by diuerÅ¿e places. Next, becauÅ¿e this God hath choÅ¿en his lodging, and hath Å¿et downe his throne, to make his reÅ¿idence in the conÅ¿cience: Therefore, that hee may dwell in cleaneneÅ¿Å¿e, yee ought to haue a regard to his dwelling place. Thirdly, he is the Lord, yea, the only Lord of this conÅ¿cience, who hath power onely to controle, who only hath power to Å¿aue, or to caÅ¿t away: therefore, that it may doe good Å¿eruice, to thy owne Lord, thou oughteÅ¿t to take heed to thy conÅ¿cience. And laÅ¿t of all, in reÅ¿pect that the health of thy Å¿oule, Å¿tandeth in the eÅ¿tate of thy conÅ¿cience, and if thy Å¿oule be in good health, thy bodie cannot bee ill: Therefore, in reÅ¿pect that the Å¿oule, and bodie, depend vpon the eÅ¿tate of the conÅ¿cience, euery one of you, Å¿hould carefully
looke to your conÅ¿ciences: I will not amplifie this, but leaue it to your memories: how the health of the Å¿oule, and welfare of the Å¿oule, Å¿hould be kept. Next, I come in the third, and laÅ¿t place to the points, in the which, euerie one of you, Å¿hould trie, and examine your conÅ¿ciences. And as yee may remember, I Å¿et downe two points, wherein ye ought to put your conÅ¿ciences in triall: FirÅ¿t, to know whether your conÅ¿ciences were at peace with God, or not: Secondly, whether your conÅ¿ciences, were in loue, in charitie, and in amitie with your neighbour, or not: In theÅ¿e two points cheefly, yee muÅ¿t trie, and examine your Å¿elues. To know, whether ye bee at peace with God, or not, ye muÅ¿t firÅ¿t trie, whether yee be in the faith or not (as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿aith) whether yee bee in the faith of ChriÅ¿t, or not: For being in the faith, and iuÅ¿tified thereby, on necesÅ¿itie, yee muÅ¿t haue peace with God. Then the next care muÅ¿t bee, to try your faith, and to Å¿ee whether ye haue faith, or not. Faith can no waies be tried, but by the fruits: faith cannot be iudged on by me, that looke vpon it only, but by the effects. Therefore, to try whether ye be in the faith or not, mark
the fruits; Take heed to thy mouth, take heed to thy hand, take heede to thy words, and to thy deeds: for except thou glorifie God in thy mouth, and confeÅ¿Å¿e to thy Å¿aluation, & except thou glorifie him alÅ¿o in thy deedes, & make thy holy life, a witnes of thy holy faith, all is but vaine, all is but meere hypocriÅ¿ie: How a Å¿incere faith is knowen. Therefore to knowe the Å¿inceritie of thy faith, thou muÅ¿t take heede, that there be a harmonie, between thy hand, thy mouth, and thy hart, that there be a natural conÅ¿ent, that thy doings preiudge not thy hart, that thy mouth preiudge not thy heart, but that mouth, and hand may teÅ¿tifie, the Å¿inceritie of the hart: If the heart, the hand, & the mouth, conÅ¿ent, & agree in one harmonie together; No queÅ¿tion, that heart that breakes forth into Å¿o good fruits, is coupled with God; There is no queÅ¿tion, the light of thy actions, the beames and Å¿hining of thy life, Å¿hall make the name of thy good God, to bee glorified.

Therefore, the whole weight of our triall, Å¿tandes cheefely vpon this point, to Å¿ee whether wee bee in the fayth, or not; to trie and examine, whether ChriÅ¿t dwell in vs by fayth, or not:
for without fayth, there canne be no coupling, or conioyning betwixt vs, & ChriÅ¿t; without faith, our hearts cannot bee Å¿anctified, and cleanÅ¿ed; and without faith, we cannot worke by charitie: Å¿o all depends, on this onely. And therefore that yee might the better vnderÅ¿tand, whether yee haue fayth, or no: I was Å¿omewhat the more exact in this matter, and I beganne to let you Å¿ee, how the holy Å¿pirit createth faith, & works faith in your Å¿oules, hearts, and mindes: I began to Å¿hewe you, what order the holy Å¿pirit kept, in forming, and in creating this notable inÅ¿trument, in your hearts, and mindes. Not onely, how hee ingenders, and begins fayth, but alÅ¿o, how he intertaines it, how he nouriÅ¿heth it. And I Å¿hewed you, the externall means, and inÅ¿truments, which hee vÅ¿eth to this effect: To beget faith in our Å¿oules, the holy Å¿pirit vÅ¿eth the hearing of the word, preached by him that is Å¿ent, & the miniÅ¿terie of the Sacraments, as ordinarie meanes, and inÅ¿truments: which ordinary meanes, are onely then effectuall, when as the holy Å¿pirit, concurs inwardly in our hearts, with the word Å¿triking outwardly in our eares, and with the Sacrament outwardly
receiued: And except the holy Å¿pirit grant his concurrence to the word, and Sacrament; word, and Sacrament both will not worke faith. So, all depends, vpon the working of this holy Å¿pirit: The whole regeneration of mankind, the renewing of the heart, and of the conÅ¿cience, depend on the power of the holy Å¿pirit; And therefore it behoueth vs, carefully to imploy our Å¿elues, in calling vpon God for his holy Å¿pirit. By the Å¿ame means, and no other, that the holy Å¿pirit beg â¢ ts faith in vs, by the Å¿ame meanes, hee nouriÅ¿heth, and augments that, which hee hath begotten: And therefore, as we got faith by the hearing of the word, Å¿o by continuall, and diligent hearing, we haue this faith augmeÌted, & nouriÅ¿hed in vs. And from hence I tooke my exhortation, That if yee would haue that Å¿pirituall life nouriÅ¿hed in you, and if yee would haue a further aÅ¿Å¿urance of heauen; of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, yee muÅ¿t both continually, and diligently, heare the bleÅ¿Å¿ed word of God.

Now it reÅ¿teth, that euery one of you carefully apply this doctrine to your owne Å¿oules, and enter into the triall of your owne conÅ¿ciences, To Å¿ee if this faith,
as I Å¿pake, be begunne in your hearts, and mindes, or not: how farre, or how little, the holy Å¿pirit hath proceeded in that worke, trie with mee, and I with you. The firÅ¿t effect of the holy Å¿pirit, whereby yee may trie your mindes, whether yee be in the faith, o â¢ not, is this: Reuolue in your memories, and remember, if at any time, it pleaÅ¿ed the Lord, in his mercie, to turn the darkneÅ¿Å¿e of your mindes into light, to cauÅ¿e that naturall darkneÅ¿Å¿e, which was within you, to depart: Through the which darkneÅ¿Å¿e, neyther had yee an eye, to Å¿ee your Å¿elues, what you were by nature, nor yet had ye an eye, to Å¿ee God in ChriÅ¿t, nor anie parte of his mercie. Examine I Å¿ay, whether this darkneÅ¿Å¿e of the naturall vnderÅ¿tanding, bee turned into light, by the working of the Å¿pirit, or not: If thou art become a childe of the light, a childe of the day; If thou art become (as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peaketh) light in the Lord: If there bee this alteration made in thy minde; That whereas naturally before, it was cloÅ¿ed vp in darkneÅ¿Å¿e, whereas it was filled with vanities, and errors, wherens it was cloÅ¿ed vp, in blindnes: If the Lord hath at anie time, inlightened
the eye of thy minde, and made thee to Å¿ee thine owne miÅ¿erie, to Å¿ee the vglineÅ¿Å¿e of thine owne nature, to Å¿ee the heinous Å¿ins, in the which by nature thou lieÅ¿t; If hee hath granted to thee, an inÅ¿ight of thy Å¿elfe, in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure; and on the other Å¿ide, if hee hath granted thee the remedie, and hath giuen thee, an inÅ¿ight of the mercie of God, in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us, if thou haÅ¿t obtained an inÅ¿ight of the riches of his grace in ChriÅ¿t; No doubt, the holy Å¿pirit hath begunne a good worke worke in thee: A worke, which will bring forth repentance, which in his owne time, hee will perfect: So this is the firÅ¿t care, which yee ought to haue, and the firÅ¿t point, wherein yee ought to examine your minds, To Å¿ee, if there bee any light in it, whereby, yee may know your miÅ¿erie, and haue an inÅ¿ight of the free mercie of God, in ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. This being done, that thou findeÅ¿t a Å¿ight of theÅ¿e two in thy minde, from thy minde goe to thy heart: and as thou haÅ¿t tryed thy minde, Å¿o try thy heart: And firÅ¿t, examine thine heart, if it bee altered, or not, that the will of it, bee framed, and bowed to GODs
obedience, that thy affection bee turned into the life of God, and bee poured out on him, as it was poured out on vanities, on filthineÅ¿Å¿e, and on the world before. Try, whether the ground of thy heart, and the fountaine from whence thy motions, and affections proceede, bee Å¿anctified, or not: for from a holy fountaine, holy waters muÅ¿t diÅ¿till: from a holy fountaine, holy motions, holy cogitations, and Å¿anctified conÅ¿iderations, muÅ¿t flowe.

Trie then, and examine your hearts, if the Å¿pirit of God hath wrought any Å¿uch reformation, as I Å¿peake of in your harts, or not. And that ye may perceiue the working of the holy Spirit the better in your hearts, and conÅ¿ciences (for the holy Spirit hath his chiefe reÅ¿idence in your hearts) I will declare vnto you, the firÅ¿t effect, that euer the holy Å¿pirit bringeth forth in the heart, in framing it, in mollifying it, and in bowing it, vnto the obedience of God: You Å¿hall knowe the working of the holy Å¿pirit, by this effect: namely, if your mindes Å¿ee, and behold, what is ill; Å¿ee, and behold what is good; perceiue, and diÅ¿cerne your owne miÅ¿erie, and your Å¿innes, which haue brought this miÅ¿erie
